In 1975, as I laid up in a circular electric bed with a C-5 and a C-4 vertabra fracture, not knowing if I will ever be able to wipe my own butt again, some of you would have wished me death as that is no life worthy to be living. 
 
 Myself, all I wanted to do was live. Paralyzed or not, I just didn't want to die. But as luck would have it, I totally recovered and I am stronger today that I ever was before my accident.
 
 Life at any cost. Unless you've been there, you don't understand. It's easy to say, in good health, just how you do or do not want to live. But until you are in that situation, you truly do not have a clue as to how you really feel.

 As a general clarification, the part of my original post that represents my position is the part that says "This is a clear example of the very real, existing, fundamental, irrevocable, and essential right: the right to life."
 
 The first part of my post was me spouting off a bunch of phrases I have heard people use to justify abortion, and should be read as general sarcasm. The last part, however, clearly shows that I believe in the fundamental right to life, which includes, but is not limited to, the right not to be aborted.

1. What type of a creator and what is your basis?
 2. How does abortion fit into this perceived nurturing responsibility?
As I said, if you do not believe in a Creator (and that is fine if you don't), carrying a fertilized ovum to term has been the province of the female of our species since time immemorial. I trust that determination. I prefer it stay that way rather than handing over the control of that area to a government.
Howard Beale

As a general clarification, the part of my original post that represents my position is the part that says "This is a clear example of the very real, existing, fundamental, irrevocable, and essential right: the right to life."
You forget the most important part of that "right to life". We have been endowed by our Creator with certain inalienable rights. The right to life is one of these.
 
 If that is the basis of our rights, then we need to acknowledge that this same Creator endowed the province of carrying of the fertilized ovum to the female of our species. We need to trust that decision. To take the position that a government take that endowment of the Creator away from the female is to undermine the very source of our rights.

How does abortion fit into this perceived nurturing responsibility?
I have opened a new thread on this subject, but it must be pretty obvious that what I am saying is that no government should take from any person that which was endowed by the Creator and the Creator endowed the province of decisions about the fertilized ovum she is carrying when she is pregnant to the female of the species. We cannot give the government the power to demand she terminate the pregnancy or demand that she carry to term. Those decisions are part and parcel of the inalienable rights endowed by the Creator to the female of the species. If we give government the power of one of those rights endowed b y the creator, then we undermine all other rights endowed by that Creator.

 It doesn't matter. It's not a popularity contest and he's not up for re-election. Approval polls mean very little, in the grand scheme of things. Clinton had very high approval ratings, but his VP didn't get his office. Bush has low approval rating right now, but there is no indication there is going to be any sort of 'housecleaning' in Washington anytime soon. The thing is, many people that vote for Bush are principle voters. That means that even though they may not approve of the way Bush is being president, they may still vote for him because the alternative is so unsettling. You could have the election again right now and with some campaigning he could very well win again.
 
 I doubt Bush gives a worry in the least about his approval rating. And that's exactly WHY many would probably vote for him again. Being popular is not a president's mandate--or at least it shouldn't be.
